Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Microscopic Charge Exchange in Heterogeneous Organic Thin Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Aaron Massari of the University of Minnesota and his graduate and undergraduate student colleagues are investigating the ways that microscopic heterogeneity influence the physical properties in molecular electronic materials. Prof. Massari's research uses sophisticated spectroscopic techniques to measure the molecular dynamics in materials while they are being electrically driven. The ultimate goal of research like this is to develop better electronic materials. Students working in the Massari group receive training in ultrafast laser techniques and in cutting-edge spectroscopic and optical methods. The Massari group also conducts educational outreach trips to do hands-on chemistry activities with large numbers of students and teachers from rural, geographically-isolated parts of Minnesota, through the University of the Prairie program at the University of Minnesota Southwest Regional Outreach Center.

Prof. Aaron Massari and his research group conduct a series of experiments to probe the ways in which molecular-scale heterogeneity in molecular electronic materials impacts performance. Specifically, Massari and his group use two-dimensional infrared spectroscopy to probe short-range charge exchange in materials with variable amounts of heterogeneity. Specific molecular systems to be studied include a number of ruthenium-based dyes (N3, Z907, etc.) as well as some indoline-based dyes (D102, D149, etc.) p-doped with iodine. Additional experiments use organic p-dopants. Experiments are combined with MD simulations to help with the modeling/analysis. The specific goals of the research include: (1) measuring and modeling the site-to-site carrier exchange in thin molecular films; (2) identifying the role of molecular aggregation on charge transport in both dye systems, and (3) investigating the influence of the nature of p-type dopants on the charge transport phenomenon. The Massari research group includes active involvement by a diverse group of undergraduates in research, including students from groups underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two-dimensional infrared (2D-IR) spectroscopy is a technique that can monitor the flow of energy within the molecule?s structure and to and from neighboring molecules. The overriding objective of this project was to use 2D-IR to disentangle the relationship between chemical structure and charge transport in heterogeneous systems. The approach was to prepare molecular thin films on surfaces and use this technique to follow the follow of energy and charges through the system. Computational modeling was employed to enhance the depth of knowledge gained from these measurements.  

A first system studied was a compound called Shvo?s catalyst, which carries out hydrogenation reactions to convert chemical feedstocks into more complex materials.  Shvo?s catalyst has four vibrations that provided handles for our technique to monitor the flow of energy through the molecule. As an example, Figure 1 shows a 2D-IR spectrum collected from this species. The peaks on the diagonal show vibrational energy that has not migrated through the molecule; the peaks off of the diagonal indicate energy that has flowed from one vibration into another vibration.  By monitoring the volume of these peaks as a function of time (the ?dynamics?) we can determine the rate of energy movement.  Our analysis uncovered the movement of a hydrogen nucleus as it initiated the first steps leading up to a chemical reaction.  This provided important insight into the catalytic mechanism of the complex so that it might be exploited to produce new materials.

In another study, we monitored vibrations on the surfaces of silicon nanoparticles. We were showed energy transfer between the vibrations in these different nanoparticle surface domains (shown schematically in Figure 2). Interestingly, we found that energy exchange was shut down by the inclusion of a very small number of impurity atoms (boron, B) per nanoparticle. We concluded that the impurities reside in the exterior shell and that energy exchange only occurs along domain boundaries on the silicon surface. Understanding the flow of vibrational energy over the surfaces of particles in this way enables one to enhance relaxation of modes and decrease the reactivity of nanoparticle surfaces. This has important ramifications for thermal transport in nanoparticle films that could improve their performance in photovoltaic systems to benefit society.

The longer a vibration continues to vibrate, the longer we are able to measure the dynamics of the system.  We investigated the influence of atomic mass on vibrational relaxation in a series of compounds in which the mass of the central atom was varied systematically down group 14 of the periodic table (silicon, germanium, and tin). Our results demonstrated that the vibrational lifetime increased when the mass of the central atom increased. This knowledge could benefit a wide range of fields in which vibrations are used to probe structure and dynamics.

A noteworthy measurement was carried out on a ruthenium-based catalyst with enhanced performance in an alumina matrix (Figure 3). Our vibrational analysis showed that the catalyst undergoes a structural change to form a metal hydride anion. This work initiated a new collaboration with a group at the University of Minnesota who synthesized model compounds to confirm our assignment. This work provided the first conclusive experimental evidence that the catalyst spontaneously converts to a hydride species in the alumina matrix. The formation of a ruthenium hydride undoubtedly impacts the increased catalytic activity of the entrapped molecule. This understanding could lead to faster, more efficient chemical reactions.

Researchers under this award also integrated research and teaching through an enormously successful outreach activity called Energy and U, which impacted over 10,000 grade school kids each year (2020 was an exception due to the Covid-19 pandemic). This activity is a collaborative effort between the PI and the Dept of Theater, Arts, and Dance. In 2019, for the 9th year in a row, the PI and his students also directed the ?Chemistry track? in the University on the Prairie program, organized by the Cottonwood County 4H program. The PI and nearly his entire research group traveled to rural Minnesota for a three-day long event working with 60 participants in grades 7-12 from rural, geographically isolated portions of the state. The themes of these events reflect topics of societal importance, such as environmental chemistry.
